block.p: INTERNATIONAL

Americans and Iraqi Exiles Sought Prewar Alliances The United States military, the C.I.A. and Iraqi exiles began a covert effort in Iraq at least three months before the war to forge alliances with military leaders and persuade commanders not to fight.
Intelligence reports say many Islamic militants who fled Iraq during the war have returned and are planning to conduct major terrorist attacks on the occupying forces.
INTERNATIONAL

Americans and Iraqi Exiles Sought Prewar Alliances The United States military, the C.I.A. and Iraqi exiles began a covert effort in Iraq at least three months before the war to forge alliances with military leaders and persuade commanders not to fight.
Intelligence reports say many Islamic militants who fled Iraq during the war have returned and are planning to conduct major terrorist attacks on the occupying forces.

Officials of the occupying powers in Iraq announced the apprehension of the former Iraqi minister of interior. They also announced the seizure of a ship believed to be smuggling diesel oil out of southern Iraq.
Iran Will Try Qaeda Suspects The Iranian minister of intelligence said any foreigners suspected of ties to Al Qaeda whose home countries have refused to take them back would be tried in Iran.

Liberian Presidential Successor Vice President Moses Blah of Liberia is expected to become President Charles Taylor's successor. Rebels are demanding that a neutral figure be named to lead a transition government.
Chinese Reburied in America Thousands of Chinese have been exhumed by their descendants and reburied in places like New York and California, often places they never saw in life.
NATIONAL

As Campaign Tightens, Kerry Sharpens Message Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts is frequently stuck in the shadow of Howard Dean in the campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. Three months ago, many Democrats thought Senator Kerry was gliding to the nomination.
Economic Upturn Holds Mortgage refinancing is fading, but business spending on the tools of production is picking up, sustaining a tenuous, incipient economic upturn.
Army Burns Chemical Arms The Army began burning the first of millions of pounds of chemical weapons stored in Alabama, despite outcries from worried residents.
Terror Alert System Is Faulted A Congressional report suggests changing the government's color-coded terrorist alert system, calling it too vague.
Ban for Flame Retardants California will become the first state to ban flame retardants, which are suspected of contributing to learning disorders in children.

On With the Show in California Spectators and camera crews outnumbered candidates at some county election offices, where the biggest name contenders filed papers by the registration deadline for the Oct. 7 recall vote for Gov. Gray Davis of California.
NEW YORK/REGION

Deck Collapse Kills One A 68-year-old woman died and three other people sustained injuries when a deck they were standing on at the rear of a house in Queens collapsed during a birthday party, the authorities said. The collapse occurred about 6:45 p.m. at 37-11 221st Street in an affluent section of Bayside, police said.
Fresh Air Fund
EDUCATION

Fight Over Religion Studies A Federal judge in Detroit ruled last month that Michigan had probably engaged in religious discrimination when it revoked a financial aid award after a college student chose to major in theology. Eleven states prohibit aid for the study of theology.
OBITUARIES

Nizar Hamdoon Iraq's former ambassador to the United States and the United Nations was 59. An important representative of Saddam Hussein's government in the 1980's and 1990's, he also served as a deputy foreign minister.
Chess
32 Weather
